summary: human infection with one of these novel highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A(H5N1) viruses was first recognized during the 1997 outbreak in Hong Kong S.A.R. of China. since 2003, outbreaks of HPAI A(H5N1) have occurred among poultry in Asia, Europe and Africa. the consequences have worsened with 382 infected human cases and 241 deaths as of April, 2008. sensitivity of RT-LAMP is not stable due to rapid changes of A (H5N1) influenza virus genotypes. new primers may be applicable for all the clades and subclades of A(H5N1) influenza viruses based on the lower number of mismatches to the reference sequences. a total of 41 specimens, including throat swabs and tracheal aspirates, were collected from HPAI infection-suspected patients in 2007. seven patients were confirmed as A(H5N1) cases as reported by WHO.
